text:
How important are Forrester Wave reports in the buyers' journey?

Context: I was doing some research for a client and a lot of people in that space have them listed on their site so it made me curious and I was wondering what this group thought about them! I personally have never even thought about them but maybe it's different in enterprise spaces / if you're selling to the C-Suite?

text:
That was super awesome! Thank you <@U019F15SA7Q> for organizing this and hosting. You are a great facilitator.

I wanted to summarize some key discussion points and it seems like everyone on the call is keen for another January session. (Note: We should take a screenshot next time to share in the group :D)

*Finding & Manager Writers*
• Finding great writers is hard, but some are willing to negotiate rates if they get consistency (think of it as a bulk discount)
• Working with premium agencies is worth it if you're looking to get the job done well
• Look at blog articles within your industry/niche and reach out to the writers
• Use LinkedIn search! Search who you need to find (ex: HR Tech Writer) and reach out to that person. The people who are serious will generally have updated LinkedIns.
    ◦ If you are a freelance writer, make sure your LinkedIn is updated and you have some of your work showcased in the "Features" section
• If you're a freelancer, find a freelance buddy that you can refer clients back and forth with (as your styles and niches may be different)
*How to focus when there's shiny object syndrome*
• Have an accountability partner - this can be someone paid like an assitant or a buddy you can check-in with
• Decide if the work meets business objectives
• Use priority matrix to figure out if the work is a quick win, not worth doing, or needs more time to plan
*How to give feedback to writers*
• You can set up a system for new writers (set expectations)
    ◦ Ex from <@U024K88ECFN>: When she hires new writers, they'll get feedback every Friday during the first month. After that, they can expect a feedback email once a month
    ◦ Book reco on <https://www.amazon.com/Radical-Candor-Revised-Kick-Ass-Humanity-ebook/dp/B07P9LPXPT/|how to give constructive feedback>

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
Seriously though, I'm floored by the enthusiasm and so grateful to each person that came out. I'll talk to Jimmy about scheduling another one soon :slightly_smiling_face:

text: They can be pretty important in large enterprise buying committees because not every single one of the people in that team of 20, 50 or even 100+ people is going to be able to do an in depth analysis of the technology. And it can be difficult for the average person to parse out the difference between software that is basically all the same in theory, so they rely on analyst reports like the Waves to 1) narrow it down to a few top choices, which that organization will potentially issue an RFP to, 2) explain in more objective terms what the actual differences are, and 3) provide third party validation of their choice. Reviews and vendor materials can be extremely noisy.
